image.altText: A train which has been smashed and derailed sitting across train tracks

items.synopsis: A freight rail operator says alternative transport arrangements are being made for Darwin supermarkets following a derailment in Katherine.

title.children: Minimal disruptions expected to Darwin supermarket supplies following freight train derailment

image.altText: A two lane highway cut through red rock. No landscaping.

items.synopsis: The Northern Territory’s Infrastructure Commissioner says plans dating back to the 1980s to upgrade a notorious intersection in Darwin were handed over to a contractor in 2021, before the project suffered numerous cost blowouts.

title.children: Original cost of troubled overpass based on 1980s designs, amid $100m blowout

image.altText: Worker near fertiliser bag

items.synopsis: In the hunt for cheaper fertiliser, has Australia imported incorrectly labelled and potentially risky product?

title.children: Farmers warned about unlabelled fertiliser, as imports rise from different supply chains

image.altText: A man in glasses and a suit stands between Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander flags.

items.synopsis: A lease held by the Russian Federation for an embassy close to Parliament House has been cancelled by the federal government.

title.children: Government rushes through law to stop new Russian embassy being built near Parliament House

image.altText: Liberal Senator David Van

items.synopsis: Opposition Leader Peter Dutton says Senator David Van has been advised he will not sit in the Liberal party room after receiving further allegations against him following a statement made by Senator Lidia Thorpe in the Senate.

title.children: Peter Dutton dumps Senator David Van from Liberal party room

image.altText: People walking past the outside of the Reserve Bank of Australia in Sydney.

items.synopsis: Stronger than expected jobs data has some economists predicting another interest rate rise will be imminent, while New Zealand's economy has entered a recession. Follow live.

title.children: Risk of interest rate rise increases as unemployment rate drops to 3.6pc, ASX continues to gain

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ASX closed higher on Thursday, up 0.2% to 7,175 points. The gains were largely led by modest jumps in the financials and real estate sectors, up 0.8% and 0.7% respectively. Healthcare shed 1.6% while utilities and academic and educational services were down 0.5% each. The top five performers for the day were: Insurance Australia Group +4.6% Aurizon Holdings +4.5% New Hope Corporation +4.3% Coronado Global Resources +4% Fortescue Metals +3.6% At the other end, the bottom five stocks were: Imugene -9.5% Lynas Rare Earth -6.5% Syrah Resources -5% West African Resources -4.6% Pilbara Minerals -4.5% And that brings today's blog to a close — thanks for following along throughout the day. We'll be back with the final day of trade tomorrow, but until then you can catch up on today's developments below, or download the ABC News app and subscribe to our range of news alerts for the latest news.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX finishes higher led by financial and real estate gains

children.content: The ASX closed higher on Thursday, up 0.2% to 7,175 points.
The gains were largely led by modest jumps in the financials and real estate sectors, up 0.8% and 0.7% respectively.
Healthcare shed 1.6% while utilities and academic and educational services were down 0.5% each.
The top five performers for the day were:
Insurance Australia Group +4.6%
Aurizon Holdings +4.5%
New Hope Corporation +4.3%
Coronado Global Resources +4%
Fortescue Metals +3.6%
At the other end, the bottom five stocks were:
Imugene -9.5%
Lynas Rare Earth -6.5%
Syrah Resources -5%
West African Resources -4.6%
Pilbara Minerals -4.5%
And that brings today's blog to a close — thanks for following along throughout the day.
We'll be back with the final day of trade tomorrow, but until then you can catch up on today's developments below, or
download the
ABC News app
and
subscribe to our range of news alerts
for the latest news.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Today's stronger than expected unemployment data suggests that future interest rate hikes aren't out of the question. Sean Langcake from Oxford Economics believes last week's rate hike, which took the cash rate to 4.1%, won't be the last one. "The labour market remains very tight, which will contribute to stronger wage growth over 2023 – compounding the upcoming increase in award wages," he wrote. "We expect to see two more rate hikes before the RBA takes a protracted pause."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Stronger than expected jobs figures paves the way for interest rate rises

children.content: Today's stronger than expected unemployment data suggests that future interest rate hikes aren't out of the question.
Sean Langcake from Oxford Economics believes last week's rate hike, which took the cash rate to 4.1%, won't be the last one.
"The labour market remains very tight, which will contribute to stronger wage growth over 2023 – compounding the upcoming increase in award wages," he wrote.
"We expect to see two more rate hikes before the RBA takes a protracted pause."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Official jobs data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics estimates that nearly 76,000 jobs were added to the economy last month, sending unemployment down to 3.6%. The strong figures came as a shock to economists, who were typically expecting 15,000 jobs to be added last month and the unemployment rate to remain steady at 3.7%.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Unemployment rate drops to 3.6% as 76,000 jobs added to the economy

children.content: Official jobs data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics estimates that nearly 76,000 jobs were added to the economy last month, sending unemployment down to 3.6%.
The strong figures came as a shock to economists, who were typically expecting 15,000 jobs to be added last month and the unemployment rate to remain steady at 3.7%.

image.altText: A drone shot of rows of houses in Shell Cove, Wollongong's south.

items.synopsis: Australia needs an ambitious national project to fix our housing crisis, researchers say.

title.children: Australia's housing policies make 'the wealthiest the most subsidised cohort' and experts say that needs to change

image.altText: A man wearing a light blue suit looks out the corner of his eyes as he walks up steps

items.synopsis: Kurtley Beale will stand trial after being accused of sexually assaulting a woman in the bathroom of a hotel in Sydney's eastern suburbs.

title.children: 'The truth will come out': Wallabies star Kurtley Beale pleads not guilty to sexual assault

items.synopsis: It was a Sunday afternoon in Port Arthur in 1996 when the three people Walter Mikac loved most were brutally taken from him.

title.children: Nine days after Walter lost his entire family, he sent a letter that helped change the course of Australian history

image.altText: The PwC logo is shown on an office building.

items.synopsis: PricewaterhouseCoopers began work on a top-level consulting contract with the federal government's regulator of tertiary colleges 24 hours before agreeing to acquire a $5.5 million stake in one such college, the controversial Top Education Group.

title.children: PwC worked for tertiary education regulator as it acquired stake in college

image.altText: A man wearing a black cap fixes the collar of Trump's white jumper.

items.synopsis: Many of the familiar faces that surrounded Donald Trump in his final days in the White House have exited his orbit. But there is one man who remained dutifully by his side — and his loyalty may have made him a target of the FBI.

title.children: How the man who was constantly by Trump’s side ended up in court as his co-defendant

image.altText: Side by side photos of Anthony Albanese, looking up in a green tie, and Donald Trump, looking serious in a red tie

items.synopsis: Two years after Anthony Albanese openly criticised Donald Trump, the prime minister is now being urged to prepare for the very real possibility of his return to the White House, writes David Speers.

title.children: What would another Trump presidency mean for Australia?

image.altText: Plastic bags full of meth.

items.synopsis: Federal police have pulled off one of Australia's biggest drug busts, seizing six tonnes of liquid and crystal meth that was hidden in shipments of canola oil bottles destined for Melbourne.

title.children: Charges laid over 'eye-watering' meth bust that stopped $1.7 billion worth of drugs from reaching Australia

image.altText: A pregnant woman using a mobile phone

items.synopsis: Many Australians use phone apps to help track their periods, for convenience, contraception or to better understand fertility and reproductive health, but privacy experts warn they're not without risk.

title.children: Many Australians use period-tracker apps for convenience, but experts warn they could come at a cost

image.altText: Nick Kyrgios hits a ball during the US Open first round against Thanasi Kokkinakis

items.synopsis: Australian tennis star Nick Kyrgios reveals he attended a mental health hospital in 2019, as he battled alcohol and drug abuse. Warning: This story contains themes of self-harm and suicide.

title.children: 'You could tell I was hurting': Kyrgios says he attended mental health hospital after 2019 tournament

image.altText: A composite graphic featuring a financial graph overlaying a photo of two Ezidi men in Toowoomba, Queensland, 2023

items.synopsis: Financial pressure on households has never been higher, and more of us are spending beyond our means than ever before, according to a long-running survey.

title.children: Almost 2 million rental households struggling to make ends meet, new report finds

image.altText: Aerial view Couran Cove Island resort

items.synopsis: Cheap waterfront properties are listed for sale at Couran Cove near the Gold Coast, but the real estate ads leave out an important detail — they have no power or water.

title.children: It's advertised as a 'resort-style paradise', but real estate ads ignore the fact it has no power or water

image.altText: A calico cat with orange, black and white fur in a bush.

items.synopsis: Halls Gap residents face a fine if caught with a cat as part of a ban that has spanned three decades.

title.children: This tiny town banned residents from owning cats 30 years ago to protect native wildlife. But did it work?

image.altText: A cow stands beneath an irrigation pivot which has been knocked over in a storm

items.synopsis: When Scott Fraser arrived at Pardoo Station from inland Queensland, he was not expecting to face one of Australia's most severe cyclones.

title.children: Multi-million dollar clean-up continues after 'mind-boggling' damage to Pardoo Station

image.altText: Young male migrants standing on a boat waiting for rescue.

items.synopsis: At least 79 migrants drown, with hundreds more said to be missing after their overloaded boat capsized and sank off Greece, in one of Europe's deadliest shipwrecks in several years.

title.children: At least 79 dead, hundreds more missing after Greece's deadliest shipwreck in years

image.altText: Woman and young child look at a pile of floral tributes lid at the site of the Hunter Valley bus crash

items.synopsis: As part of a joint operation, NSW Police and the National Heavy Vehicle Regulator have inspected vehicles and documents at the bus depot of the company involved in the deadly bus crash in the NSW Hunter Valley.

title.children: Buses, documents, driver management under police spotlight in wake of Hunter Valley tragedy

image.altText: Several detention centre inmates in the yard. One is bashing his hands against the fence.

items.synopsis: After years of assaults, escapes and riots, the Malmsbury Youth Justice centre will close. But staff say it was not the outcome they wanted, as the union prepares for action.

title.children: Staff call it the 'worst workplace in Victoria' but have concerns about youth justice centre's closure

image.altText: A person with denim jacket and cap seen from behind sitting outdoors at a table looking at phone with laptop open.

items.synopsis: Most cryptocurrencies don't have a head office or a CEO, which makes regulating them tough. But expert Gavin Brown says ignoring their power is not an option.

title.children: 'This is dangerous': This expert says governments have their fingers in their ears about cryptocurrency

image.altText: A picture of a screen using biometric surveillance on an elderly couple walking in a public space.

items.synopsis: European Union politicians agree to draft artificial intelligence (AI) rules that include a blanket ban on the use of the technology in biometric surveillance and predictive policing systems.

title.children: EU agrees on draft AI rules including ban on facial recognition surveillance

image.altText: Aboriginal people in a NT community - generic image

items.synopsis: Life outcomes for Indigenous Australians are continuing to worsen, as initiatives to Close the Gap offer mixed outcomes in the pursuit of ending systemic disadvantage.

title.children: Government says updated Closing the Gap data highlights need for structural change

image.altText: Vintage tractor

items.synopsis: Vintage tractor enthusiasts campaign to block the export of the International Titan Model D, built in 1912, that they say has significant cultural heritage value.

title.children: Collectors attempt to block the export of 111-year-old tractor they say belongs in Australian hands

image.altText: a surfer on a large wave

items.synopsis: Unstable weather off southern WA could see huge swells pounding the coast from Augusta to Albany today.

title.children: Forecast huge swells prompt warnings for sightseers, excitement for surfers on WA coast
